description: From Middle French balustre, from Italian balaustro (“pillar”), from balausta (“wild pomegranate flower”), so named because of resemblance to the swelling form of the half-open flower, from Ancient Greek βαλαύστιον (balaústion), from Semitic (compare Aramaic balatz (“wild pomegranate flower”)). Doublet of banister.

entries.meaning: (architecture)  A short column used in a group to support a rail, as commonly found on the side of a stairway; a banister. [from 17th c.]
